p: Check to ensure that your application considers restricting permissions to the delegate as when it allows partially trusted callers.

You can either use an appropriate permission demand to authorize the external code when it passes the delegate to your code, or you can use a deny or permit-only stack modifier to restrict the delegate's permissions just prior to calling it. For example, the following code grants the delegate code only execution permission to constrain its capabilities.
Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
div: using System.Security;using System.Security.Permissions;...// Delegate definitionpublic delegate void SomeDelegate(string text);    public void ExecDelegateWithExcePerm(){        // Permit only execution, prior to calling the delegate. This prevents the        // delegate code accessing resources or performing other privileged        // operations        new SecurityPermission(SecurityPermissionFlag.Execution).PermitOnly();        // Now call the "constrained" delegate        SomeDelegate del = new SomeDelegate(DisplayResults);        // Revert the permit only stack modifier        CodeAccessPermission.RevertPermitOnly();}private void DisplayResults(string result){...}
pre: using System.Security;using System.Security.Permissions;...// Delegate definitionpublic delegate void SomeDelegate(string text);    public void ExecDelegateWithExcePerm(){        // Permit only execution, prior to calling the delegate. This prevents the        // delegate code accessing resources or performing other privileged        // operations        new SecurityPermission(SecurityPermissionFlag.Execution).PermitOnly();        // Now call the "constrained" delegate        SomeDelegate del = new SomeDelegate(DisplayResults);        // Revert the permit only stack modifier        CodeAccessPermission.RevertPermitOnly();}private void DisplayResults(string result){...}

using System.Security;using System.Security.Permissions;...// Delegate definitionpublic delegate void SomeDelegate(string text);    public void ExecDelegateWithExcePerm(){        // Permit only execution, prior to calling the delegate. This prevents the        // delegate code accessing resources or performing other privileged        // operations        new SecurityPermission(SecurityPermissionFlag.Execution).PermitOnly();        // Now call the "constrained" delegate        SomeDelegate del = new SomeDelegate(DisplayResults);        // Revert the permit only stack modifier        CodeAccessPermission.RevertPermitOnly();}private void DisplayResults(string result){...}

html:
What to Check For

Check to ensure that your application considers restricting permissions to the delegate as when it allows partially trusted callers.

How to Fix

You can either use an appropriate permission demand to authorize the external code when it passes the delegate to your code, or you can use a deny or permit-only stack modifier to restrict the delegate's permissions just prior to calling it. For example, the following code grants the delegate code only execution permission to constrain its capabilities.

      
using System.Security;
using System.Security.Permissions;
...
// Delegate definitionpublic 
delegate void SomeDelegate(string text);
    public void ExecDelegateWithExcePerm(){
        // Permit only execution, prior to calling the delegate. This prevents the
        // delegate code accessing resources or performing other privileged
        // operations
        new SecurityPermission(SecurityPermissionFlag.Execution).PermitOnly();
        // Now call the "constrained" delegate
        SomeDelegate del = new SomeDelegate(DisplayResults);
        // Revert the permit only stack modifier
        CodeAccessPermission.RevertPermitOnly();
}
private void DisplayResults(string result)
{
...
}

Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
